channel.title: C-SPAN Recent Events
channel.description: Recent events seen on the C-SPAN Networks. Created By Cable.
channel.copyright: Copyright (C) 2011 National Cable Satellite Corporation. All rights reserved.

item.title: Washington Journal for Wednesday, Feb. 2
item.description:
• 7:05am - Phoner Jim Michaels, USA Today, Military Writer
  • 7:15a - Phoner Dale Gavlak, Associated Press
  • 7:40am - Phoner Jim Morrill, Charlotte Observer, Political Writer
  • 7:45am - Steven Cook, Council on Foreign Relations, Senior Fellow on Middle Eastern Studies
  • 8:30am - Gary Shapiro, Author, “The Comeback: How Innovation Will Restore the American Dream”
  • 9:15am - Gretchen Morgenson, New York Times, Assistant Business & Financial Editor

item.title: State Department Briefing on Human Trafficking
item.description: Ambassador-at-Large to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons, Luis CdeBaca spoke to reporters at the State Department about the U.S. Government's new interagency initiatives to combat trafficking in persons and responded to questions.

item.title: Senate Democrat and Republican News Conferences
item.description: Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY) announced he will offer a health care repeal amendment as part of the debate on an aviation programs bill.  Because of procedural rules, Republicans will be forced to get 60 votes in order to pass the measure.  Sen. McConnell and Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-NV) each spoke to reporters after attending their weekly party policy lunches.

item.title: American Constitution Society Discussion on 2011 Judicial Nominations
item.description: White House Counsel Robert Bauer talked about the judicial nomination process and the Obama Administration’s efforts to fill vacancies on the federal bench. He was the keynote speaker at an event hosted by the American Constitution Society examining the future of the federal judiciary, the rising number of judicial vacancies and the confirmation process. Other speakers include former American Bar Association President Carolyn Lamm and the former Republican Chief Counsel on the Senate Judiciary Committee.

item.title: Defense Dept. Briefing on Afghanistan
item.description: Commander of International Security Assistance Force Joint Command, Army Lieutenant General David Rodriguez conducted a briefing at the Pentagon on current operations in Afghanistan.

item.title: Senate Judiciary Cmte. Hearing on Foreclosure Mediation Programs
item.description: The federal home foreclosure prevention program known as HAMP has not succeeded in stemming the tide of home foreclosures, according to Senator Sheldon Whitehouse (D-RI). The Senator chaired a Judiciary Committee hearing on efforts to stem the tide of home mortgage foreclosures through bankruptcy courts. The Committee heard about programs in New York and Rhode Island where the courts mediate between home owners and the banks. Senator Whitehouse has recently introduced a bill to promote these mediation programs.

item.title: Senate Budget Cmte. Hearing on Economic Outlook
item.description: The Congressional Budget Office has projected continued, but moderate economic and job growth over the next few years. The Senate Budget Committee spoke with three economists to get their points of view.  They heard from Morgan Stanley’s chief U.S. economist, an economics professor from MIT’s Sloan Management School and the former chief economist for Bear Stearns.

item.title: Washington Journal for Tuesday, Feb. 1
item.description:
• Phoner: Jim Michaels, USA Today, Military Writer
  • Martin Indyk, Adviser to George Mitchell, Special Envoy for Middle East Peace
  • David Malpass, Fmr. Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary, Reagan Administration (1986-89) & Fmr. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, George H.W. Bush Administration (1990-93)
  • Heather Boushey, Center for American Progress, Senior Economist, 
  • Dan Friedman, National Journal, Senate Leadership Reporter

item.title: Congress Examines Transition Challenges in Iraq
item.description: A new report casts a grim forecast in Iraq after U.S. troops began a withdrew from that country. It casts doubt on the country’s ability to maintain stability and rebuff the advances of terrorist organizations from regaining power.

item.title: Washington Journal for Tuesday
item.description:
• 7:05am - Jim Michaels, USA Today, Military Writer
  • 7:30am - Martin Indyk,  Asst. Secretaryof State for Near East Affairs
  • Clinton Administration, 1997-2000
  • 8am - David Malpass, Former Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary
  • Reagan Administration, 1986-89
  • 8:30am - Heather Boushey, Center for American Progress, Senior Economist
  • 9:15am - Dan Friedman, National Journal, Senate Leadership Reporter

item.title: State Department Press Briefing
item.description: State Department Spokesman P.J. Crowley confirmed that former U.S. Ambassador to Egypt Frank Wisner is in Cairo for meetings with government officials. He’ll repeat the Obama Administration’s recent call for political and economic reforms amid large anti-government protests.

item.title: White House Briefing with Press Secretary Robert Gibbs
Discussion on the Future of Pakistan
item.description: The U.S. Institute of Peace and the Brookings Institution hosted a conference on the future and Pakistan and U.S. policy towards the country. Speakers included former U.S. Ambassadors to Pakistan as well as Southeast Asia scholars.

item.title: World Economic Forum Global Economic Outlook Forum
item.description: At the World Economic Forum, finance ministers from Britain, France, and Germany, representatives from China and India, as well as the World Bank President discussed the global economic outlook. Panelists talked about the relevance of the G20, signs of market confidence, and the strength of the euro currency.

item.title: News Conference on Dietary Guidelines for Americans
item.description: Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack and Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius announced the latest dietary guidelines for Americans at a press conference held at George Washington University.  The guidelines, which are updated every five years, aim to reduce the risk of chronic diseases and obesity by encouraging improved nutrition and physical activity.

item.title: Washington Journal for Monday, Jan. 31
item.description:
• Mark Zandi, Moody’s Economy.com, Chief Economist
  • Steve Heydemann, United States Institute for Peace, Vice President
  • Michelle Garcia, National Center for Victims of Crime, Stalking Resource Center Director

item.title: American Artifacts: Frederick Douglass House
item.description: American History TV visits the Washington, D.C. home of Frederick Douglass, the ex-slave who wrote the influential "Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass," spoke out for women's rights, and pressed President Abraham Lincoln for the Emancipation Proclamation. Our tour guide is National Park Service Interpretive Ranger Kamal McClarin.

item.title: The Presidency: Daniel P. Moynihan and the Nixon White House
item.description: Prior to his career in the United States Senate, Daniel Patrick Moynihan worked in four presidential administrations. His legacy has received renewed attention following the release of his papers by the National Archives. The Nixon Foundation and Nixon Library jointly host an event focusing on Moynihan’s role in the Nixon White House.

item.title: Washington Journal for Sunday, Jan. 30
item.description:
• Phoner: Hamza Hendawi, Associated Press, Cairo Bureau Chief
  • Craig Crawford, CQ-Roll Call, Columnist
  • Tom Ridge, Former Homeland Security Secretary (2003-05)
  • John Gage, American Federation of Government Employees, President

item.title: Rep. Patrick McHenry (R-NC)
item.description: With a number of states dealing with financial difficulties and budget shortfalls, Congress faces the prospect of providing “bailout” funds to states or possibly allowing governors to file bankruptcy.
